008 *******************************************************************************/
009package imagingbook.common.filter.generic;
010
011import ij.process.ImageProcessor;
012import imagingbook.common.filter.examples.ExampleFilter3x3Scalar;
013import imagingbook.common.filter.examples.ExampleFilter3x3Vector;
014import imagingbook.common.filter.examples.FilterProgressExample;
015import imagingbook.common.ij.IjProgressBarMonitor;
016import imagingbook.common.image.GridIndexer2D;
017import imagingbook.common.image.OutOfBoundsStrategy;
018import imagingbook.common.image.PixelPack;
019import imagingbook.common.image.PixelPack.PixelSlice;
020import imagingbook.common.util.progress.ProgressMonitor;
021import imagingbook.common.util.progress.ProgressReporter;
022
023/**
024 * <p>This is the (abstract) root class of the generic filter hierarchy.
025 * Generic filters are designed to work with all types of
026 * ImageJ images, i.e., sub-classes of {@link ImageProcessor}.
027 * Filters implemented with this framework use a set of unified
028 * image data structures, all based on {@code float} values
029 * (see {@link PixelPack} and {@link PixelSlice}).
030 * Input images are transparently copied from and back to these
031 * float data, thus authors of new filters do not need to concern themselves
032 * with the original pixel data types.
033 * Behind the scenes, classes {@link GridIndexer2D} and {@link OutOfBoundsStrategy} are relevant for
034 * pixel indexing and out-of-boundary coordinates handling.
035 * </p>
036 * <p>
037 * Generic filters support multiple passes, the associated control 
038 * structures are implemented by this class {@link GenericFilter}.
039 * Most filters only require a single pass.
040 * If more passes are required, the concrete (terminal) filter class
041 * should override the method {@code passesRequired()} to return the 
042 * required number, which may change dynamically during the execution 
043 * of the filter (e.g., to reach convergence of some sort).
044 * Sub-classes provide definitions for scalar filters, i.e., filters
045 * that operate independently on the different components of color images
046 * (e.g., see {@link GenericFilterScalar}),
047 * as opposed to vector vector filters that deal with color datea as
048 * vectors (e.g., see {@link GenericFilterVector}).
049 * In addition, both types provide sub-classes for X/Y-separable versions
050 * (see {@link GenericFilterScalarSeparable} and {@link GenericFilterVectorSeparable}).
051 * </p>
052 * <p>
053 * In the simplest (though frequent) case a concrete filter class only needs 
054 * to implement a single method to specify the work to be done for calculating the
055 * value of a single image pixel (e.g., see 
056 * {@code GenericFilterVector.doPixel(PixelPack, int, int)} and
057 * {@code GenericFilterScalar.doPixel(PixelSlice, int, int)}).
058 * See {@link ExampleFilter3x3Scalar} and {@link ExampleFilter3x3Vector} for examples.
059 * </p>
060 * <p>
061 * To <strong>apply</strong> as filter to a given image, the key method is 
062 * {@link #applyTo(ImageProcessor)} (or {@link #applyTo(PixelPack)} if
063 * the pixel data are already available as a {@link PixelPack}).
064 * All filters operate destructively, i.e., by modifying the supplied image.
065 * </p>
066 * <p>
067 * {@link GenericFilter}s support asynchronous <strong>progress reporting</strong> based on the
068 * {@link ProgressMonitor} framework. Here is a usage example (from one of the sample plugins):</p>
069 * <pre>
070 * ImageProcessor ip = ... // any image
071 * ...
072 * GenericFilter filter = new TschumperleDericheFilter();
073 * try (ProgressMonitor m = new ProgressBarMonitor(filter)) {
074 *     filter.applyTo(ip);
075 * }</pre>
076 * <p>
077 * During execution of the filter, the {@link IjProgressBarMonitor} instance queries the filter
078 * periodically (in a separate thread) for its progress status and updates ImageJ's progress
079 * bar.
080 * </p>
081 * 
082 * @author WB
083 * @version 2012/01/12
084 */
085public abstract class GenericFilter implements ProgressReporter {
086        
087        private class AbortFilterException extends RuntimeException {
088                private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;
089        }
090        
091        private PixelPack source = null;
092        private PixelPack target = null;
093        private int pass = -1;
094        
095        public GenericFilter() {
096        }
097        
098        // --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
099
100        /**
101         * Returns the current filter pass number, starting with 0.
102         * @return the filter pass number
103         */
104        protected int getPass() {
105                return pass;
106        }
107        
108        /**
109         * Returns the width of the currently processed image.
110         * @return the width of the image
111         */
112        protected int getWidth() {
113                if (source == null) {
114                        throw new IllegalStateException("width is unknown unless filter is invoked");
115                }
116                return source.getWidth();
117        }
118        
119        /**
120         * Returns the height of the currently processed image.
121         * @return the height of the image
122         */
123        protected int getHeight() {
124                if (source == null) {
125                        throw new IllegalStateException("height is unknown unless filter is invoked");
126                }
127                return source.getHeight();
128        }
129        
130        /**
131         * Returns the depth (number of components) of the currently processed image.
132         * @return the depth of the image
133         */
134        protected int getDepth() {
135                if (source == null) {
136                        throw new IllegalStateException("depth is unknown unless filter is invoked");
137                }
138                return source.getDepth();
139        }
140        
141        // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
142        
143        /**
144         * Applies this filter to the given {@link PixelPack} instance, which is modified.
145         * @param source the image to be filtered
146         */
147        public void applyTo(PixelPack source) {
148                this.source = source;
149                this.target = new PixelPack(source);    // empty copy of same dimensions as source
150                runFilter(source, target);
151        }
152        
153        private void runFilter(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {    // do we always want to copy back??
154                initFilter(source, target);
155                pass = 0;
156                try {
157                        while (pass < passesRequired()) {       // TODO: check return value of passesRequired()!
158                                //IJ.log("****** starting pass " + pass);
159                                initPass(source, target);
160                                runPass(source, target);
161                                target.copyTo(this.source); // copy target back to sources
162                                pass++;
163                        }
164                } catch (AbortFilterException e) {};
165                // the filter's result is to be found in 'source'
166                closeFilter();
167                this.source = null;
168                this.target = null;
169        }
170        
171        // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
172        
173        /**
174         * Applies this filter to the given {@link ImageProcessor}, which is modified.
175         * {@link PixelPack#DefaultOutOfBoundsStrategy} is used to handle out-of-bounds coordinates.
176         * @param ip the image to be filtered
177         */
178        public void applyTo(ImageProcessor ip) {
179                applyTo(ip, PixelPack.DefaultOutOfBoundsStrategy);
180        }
181        
182        /**
183         * Applies this filter to the given {@link ImageProcessor}, which is modified;
184         * the specified {@link OutOfBoundsStrategy} is used to handle out-of-bounds coordinates.
185         * @param ip the image to be filtered
186         * @param obs the out-of-bounds strategy to be used
187         */
188        public void applyTo(ImageProcessor ip, OutOfBoundsStrategy obs) {
189                PixelPack pp = new PixelPack(ip, 1.0, obs);
190                applyTo(pp);
191                pp.copyToImageProcessor(ip);    // copy data back to ip
192        }
193        
194        // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
195        
196        // called once before the filter operations starts.
197        // 
198        // that depend on the image size
199        /**
200         * This method is called once at the start of the filter execution.
201         * It does nothing by default.
202         * Concrete filter classes should override this method, 
203         * e.g., for setting up temporary data structures.
204         * 
205         * @param source the image source data
206         * @param target the image target data
207         */
208        protected void initFilter(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {
209                // does nothing by default
210        }
211        
212        /**
213         * This method is called once at the start of each filter pass.
214         * It does nothing by default.
215         * Concrete filter classes should override this method if needed.
216         * @param source the image source data
217         * @param target the image target data
218         */
219        protected void initPass(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {
220                // does nothing by default
221        }
222        
223        // concrete sub-classes should override to purge 
224        // specific data structures if needed
225        /**
226         * This method is called once when the filter terminates.
227         * It does nothing by default.
228         * Concrete filter classes should override this method if needed.
229         */
230        protected void closeFilter() {
231        }
232        
233        // limits the necessary number of passes, which may not be known at initialization.
234        // multi-pass filters must override this method.
235        /**
236         * Returns the necessary number of passes, which may change during execution 
237         * of the filter. The value 1 is returned by default.
238         * Multi-pass filters must override this method.
239         * The filter terminates as soon as the requested number of passes is reached.
240         * This this method can be used to terminate filter execution once some desired
241         * state has been reached (e.g., convergence).
242         * See also {@link #getPass()}.
243         * 
244         * @return the required number of filter passes
245         */
246        protected int passesRequired() {
247                return 1;       // do exactly 1 pass
248        }
249        
250        /**
251         * This method can be called to abort the filter execution prematurely,
252         * e.g. for debugging.
253         */
254        protected final void abort() {
255                throw new AbortFilterException();
256        }
257
258        /**
259         * This method performs one pass of the filter, it must be implemented by a sub-class.
260         * There is usually no need for a custom filter class to override this method.
261         * 
262         * @param source the image source data
263         * @param target the image target data
264         */
265        protected abstract void runPass(PixelPack source, PixelPack target);
266        
267        // progress reporting ----------------------------------------------------------------
268
269        @Override
270        public final double getProgress() {
271                double fp = reportProgress();
272                return this.reportProgress(fp);
273        }
274        
275        // 
276        /**
277         * This method is called asynchonously and may be overridden by the terminal filter class 
278         * if it does extensive work that should be monitored. 
279         * In this case the method must return a value between 0 and 1, reflecting the degree of completion
280         * (only of the final class's subtask) at the time of invocation.
281         * Normally this is not necessary, since the intermediate classes
282         * return their own progress state (for the less granular tasks) anyways.
283         * The default implementations returns 0 (progress).
284         * See {@link FilterProgressExample} for an example.
285         * @return the degree of completion (0,...,1)
286         */
287        protected double reportProgress() {
288                return 0;
289        }
290        
291        /** This method is used for internal progress reporting through the class hierarchy. It should
292         * not be overridden or modified.
293         * 
294         * @param subProgress the current progress reported by the immediate sub-task (0,...,1)
295         * @return the cumulative progress (0,...,1)
296         */
297        protected double reportProgress(double subProgress) {
298                int pass = Math.max(getPass(), 0);      // getPass() returns -1 if loop is not started 
299                double localProgress = (pass + subProgress) / passesRequired();
300                return localProgress; // this is the final value returned to the monitor
301        }
302}
